rationale1: The text creates a conspiracy narrative about censorship and government control.
rationale2: The claim uses Availability Bias/Conspiracy by alleging 'secretly slowing down the internet'. It appeals to fears of censorship and information control.

text: Eating fish and milk together creates white spots on your skin that never go away.
rationale1: The claim uses the fear of permanent disfigurement ('never go away') to enforce a food rule.
rationale2: The headline appeals to Naturalness Bias/Food taboos. It uses Illusory Correlation to link 'fish and milk' to permanent skin disfigurement.

text: Your smartphone is recording your face every time you unlock it to build a government database.
rationale1: The headline alleges systematic surveillance integrated into daily phone usage.
rationale2: The text uses Availability Bias by claiming phones 'record your face' for a database. It turns a standard unlock feature into a surveillance tool.

text: A simple mixture of ginger and honey cures cancer better than chemotherapy, says a viral post.
rationale1: The text compares a kitchen remedy to medical treatment ('better than chemotherapy') based on a viral post.
rationale2: The claim uses Availability Bias via a 'viral post'. It exhibits Naturalness Bias by asserting that 'ginger and honey' are 'better than chemotherapy' for cancer.

text: Beware: New AI drones are flying over cities to scan people's faces for fines.
rationale1: The claim uses 'Beware' and a dystopian scenario ('drones scanning faces') to incite fear.
rationale2: The headline uses Availability Bias with 'Beware'. It imagines a dystopian scenario of 'AI drones' scanning faces to create fear of technology.

text: Drinking cold water freezes the fats in your blood and causes a heart attack.
rationale1: The rationale uses a simple physical metaphor ('freezes fats') to explain a heart attack.
rationale2: The text uses Illusory Correlation by claiming 'cold water freezes fats' in the blood. It uses a simplistic physical metaphor to explain a 'heart attack'.

text: Tech companies are hiding free energy technology because they want you to pay electricity bills.
rationale1: The headline uses an anti-corporate conspiracy to explain why energy isn't free.
rationale2: The claim uses Availability Bias/Conspiracy regarding 'hiding free energy'. It appeals to the belief that corporations suppress beneficial technology.

text: A famous yoga guru claims that clapping hands for 10 minutes cures low blood pressure.
rationale1: The text promotes a simple physical action as a cure, backed by a spiritual authority.
rationale2: The headline appeals to Naturalness Bias via a 'famous yoga guru'. It promotes a simple action ('clapping hands') as a cure for a medical condition.

text: Urgent: Do not update your WhatsApp! The new version allows strangers to see your gallery.
rationale1: The claim creates urgency ('Urgent') and a privacy threat ('see your gallery') to stop updates.
rationale2: The text uses Availability Bias with 'Urgent'. It frames a software update as a security threat ('see your gallery') to discourage updating.

text: Eating one tulsi leaf every day prevents cancer for your whole life.
rationale1: The headline offers a 'magic bullet' solution ('prevents cancer for whole life') using a sacred plant.
rationale2: The claim uses Naturalness Bias by offering a 'tulsi leaf' (sacred plant) as a total cancer preventative. It promises a lifetime of health from a simple natural habit.

text: Your router is emitting dangerous waves that are killing your house plants.
rationale1: The text uses visible evidence (dying plants) to imply invisible danger (waves) to humans.
rationale2: The headline uses Availability Bias by using visual proof ('killing house plants'). It uses Illusory Correlation to link router 'waves' to biological damage.

text: Experts say that sleeping on your stomach damages your internal organs by crushing them.
rationale1: The claim uses vague 'Experts' and violent verbs ('crushing') to warn against a sleeping position.
rationale2: The text uses Availability Bias via 'Experts say'. It uses Illusory Correlation to claim sleeping on the stomach 'crushes' internal organs, creating a violent health myth.

text: Hackers can steal your fingerprints from the photos you post on Instagram.
rationale1: The headline expands the threat of identity theft to social media photos.
rationale2: The claim uses Availability Bias by expanding identity theft to 'Instagram photos'. It creates paranoia about sharing images online.

text: Eating seeds of an apple releases cyanide that kills you instantly.
rationale1: The rationale exaggerates the toxicity of apple seeds to an immediate lethal effect.
rationale2: The headline uses Naturalness Bias (fear of toxins in nature). It uses Illusory Correlation by exaggerating the cyanide in apple seeds to an 'instant' lethal dose.

text: The government is installing secret microphones in street lights to listen to pedestrians.
rationale1: The text creates a paranoid narrative about public infrastructure being used for spying.
rationale2: The text uses Availability Bias by creating a paranoia about 'street lights'. It alleges secret government surveillance of public spaces.

text: A famous actor reveals that drinking charcoal water is the secret to his clear skin.
rationale1: The persuasion relies on celebrity beauty secrets to promote a fad diet.
rationale2: The claim uses Availability Bias via a 'famous actor'. It exhibits Naturalness Bias by promoting 'charcoal water' (a fad detox item) for beauty.

text: Warning: 5G networks activate the virus dormant in your body, says a whistleblower.
rationale1: The claim combines health fear ('activate virus') with tech fear, cited by a 'whistleblower'.
rationale2: The headline uses Availability Bias with 'Warning' and a 'whistleblower'. It uses Illusory Correlation to link '5G networks' to the activation of a 'dormant virus'.

text: Rubbing oil on your belly button cures dry eyes and cracked lips instantly.
rationale1: The headline appeals to traditional healing ('belly button oil') with the promise of instant results.
rationale2: The text appeals to Naturalness Bias/Traditional healing ('oil on belly button'). It uses Illusory Correlation to link this to the instant cure of 'dry eyes'.

text: If you get a call from 'Customer Care', hang up immediately or they will hack your phone.
rationale1: The text uses a broad warning against 'Customer Care' to create distrust and fear of hacking.
rationale2: The claim uses Availability Bias by creating a broad fear of 'Customer Care' calls. It threatens immediate hacking to trigger a defensive response.

text: Doctors are hiding this simple leaf that cures diabetes because they want to sell insulin.
rationale1: The claim uses an anti-medical establishment conspiracy ('Doctors are hiding') to sell a natural cure.
rationale2: The headline uses Availability Bias/Conspiracy ('Doctors are hiding'). It exhibits Naturalness Bias by claiming a 'simple leaf' cures diabetes better than insulin.

text: Your smart TV listens to you and sells your secrets to advertisers, reveals an insider.
rationale1: The headline uses an 'insider' source to validate the fear of devices spying on private life.
rationale2: The text uses Availability Bias via an 'insider'. It validates the fear that 'Smart TVs' are spying and selling private data.

text: Eating curd with chicken produces toxins that lead to psoriasis and skin diseases.
rationale1: The text links a specific food combination to a visible, feared disease ('psoriasis').
rationale2: The claim appeals to Naturalness Bias/Food taboos. It uses Illusory Correlation to link 'curd with chicken' to 'psoriasis', blaming diet for a skin disease.

text: The government reads every email you send to check for keywords like 'revolution'.
rationale1: The claim alleges automated government censorship of private communications.
rationale2: The headline uses Availability Bias by alleging automated email censorship. It taps into political paranoia about keyword monitoring.

text: Grandmother's advice: Drinking hot water in the morning burns all the body fat away.
rationale1: The headline offers an effortless weight loss solution ('burns all fat') based on folk wisdom.
rationale2: The text relies on Naturalness Bias/Folk wisdom ('Grandmother's advice'). It suggests 'hot water' is a miraculous, effortless way to burn 'all body fat'.

text: Alert: Hackers can now access your camera just by sending you a GIF on WhatsApp.
rationale1: The text turns a harmless media format ('GIF') into a scary hacking vector.
rationale2: The claim uses Availability Bias with 'Alert'. It creates fear about a common media type ('GIF') being a vehicle for total device compromise.

text: A famous cardiologist says that skipping dinner is the best way to prevent heart attacks.
rationale1: The persuasion relies on the authority of a 'famous cardiologist' promoting a specific diet habit.
rationale2: The headline uses Availability Bias via a 'famous cardiologist'. It promotes a specific behavior ('skipping dinner') as the ultimate heart attack prevention.
